title: R - An Introduction
text:
Basic Arithmetic

R can be regarded as a calculator

it recognizes all of the standard arithmetic operators





Code
# Basic arithmetic operations in R

1+2 

6-7 

5/2 

2^3

2+5*2^3

3*(4+5) 

(3+4)*5

sqrt(4)



modulo operators (integer division & remainder)





Code
# Modulo operators in R

5 %/% 2  # integer division
5 %% 2   # remainder

100 %/% 60 ## How many whole hours in 100 minutes?

100 %% 60 ## How many minutes are left over?




In RStudio, you can start a new script using the dropdown menu File > New File > R Script
use your R script to save finalized commands

type in the console to practice and debug, then use the script to save what worked

R scripts allow you to save comments, or annotations, to your code

anything following the # symbol in a script will not be treated like an R command—essentially, R will skip over it

title: R - An Introduction
text:
Logic

R can also be used for logical operations

it recognizes the standard logical operators





Code
1 > 2

1 > 2 & 1 > 0.5 # The "&" stands for "and"

1 > 2 | 1 > 0.5 # The "|" stands for "or" (not a pipe a la the shell)

isTRUE (1 < 2)



Here are the detailed list of logical operators in R

& and | are used for element-wise logical operations
&& and || are used for short-circuit logical operations

e.g. 1 > 2 && 1 > 0.5 will return FALSE without evaluating the second condition

! is used for negation (i.e. “not”)
==, !=, <, <=, >, and >= are used for comparison

Here is further information about logical vectors in R

Logical vectors are vectors that contain only TRUE, FALSE, or NA values
Logical vectors are often used for subsetting data frames or matrices

title: R - An Introduction
text:
Logic

Order of precedence

logic statements follow a strict order of precedence
logical operators (>, ==, etc) are evaluated before Boolean operators (& and |)

failure to recognise this can lead to unexpected behaviour






Code
1 > 0.5 & 2






Code
1 > 0.5 & 1 > 2



Lesson: explicit about each component of your logic statement(s)



2 is converted into as.logical(2)
as.logical(2) is TRUE because it is not zero



Negation: !

this will come in very handy when we start filtering data objects






Code
is.na(1:10)
!is.na(1:10)

Negate(is.na)(1:10)

title: R - An Introduction
text:
logical operators

Value matching: %in%

whether an object is contained within (i.e. matches one of) a list of items, use %in%





Code
4 %in% 1:10

4 %in% 5:10



There’s no equivalent “not in” command

but we can create one






Code
`%ni%` = Negate(`%in%`) ## The backticks (`) help to specify functions.

4 %ni% 5:10



Evaluation

use two equal signs for logical evaluation






Code
1 == 1 ## This does.

1 != 2 ## Note the single equal sign when combined with a negation




Evaluation caveat: Floating-point numbers
What do you think will happen if we evaluate 0.1 + 0.2 == 0.3?
0.1 + 0.2 == 0.3
Problem: Computers represent numbers as binary (i.e. base 2) floating-points

More here.

Fast and memory efficient, but can lead to unexpected behaviour.


Similar to the way that standard decimal (i.e. base 10) representation can’t precisely capture certain fractions

e.g. \(\frac{1}{3} = 0.3333...\)

Solution: Use all.equal() for evaluating floats (i.e fractions)

all.equal(0.1 + 0.2, 0.3)

title: R - An Introduction
text:
Assignment operators

Assignment: <- or =

use <- for assignment, but = is also acceptable
<- is the preferred operator in R, but = is more common in other programming languages





Code
a <- 10 + 5
a



nevertheless, we can use = for assignment





Code
b = 10 + 10 

b




an arrow can point in the other direction too (i.e. ->)
the following code chunk is equivalent to the previous one, although used much less frequently



Code
10 + 5 -> a



Note that the assigned object must be on the left with “=”

title: R - An Introduction
text:
Help

Use help or ? to get help on a function

e.g. ?mean will give you the documentation for the mean() function

For more information on a (named) function or object in R, consult the “help” documentation. For example:




Code
help(plot)

?plot 



Comments in R are demarcated by #.
Hit Ctrl+Shift+c in RStudio to (un)comment whole sections of highlighted code
Vignettes

for many packages, you can also try the vignette() function, which will provide an introduction to a package and it’s purpose through a series of helpful examples

e.g. vignette("ggplot2") will give you a detailed introduction to the ggplot2 package





see the Examples section at the bottom of the help file?

You can run them with the example() function
Try it: example(plot)

title: R - An Introduction
text:
Object-oriented programming (OOP) in R

R is an object-oriented programming language

everything in R is an object
objects can be manipulated and transformed using functions
functions are also objects in R

R has three main object classes

vectors
lists
data frames

R also has other object classes, such as matrices, arrays, and factors
Each object class has its own set of rules (“methods”) for determining valid operations

e.g. you can perform many of the same operations on matrices and data frames
But there are some operations that only work on a matrix, and vice versa
At the same time, you can (usually) convert an object from one type to another





Code
## Create a small data frame called "d".

d = data.frame(x = 1:2, y = 3:4) 

d






Code
## Convert it to (i.e. create) a matrix call "m".

m = as.matrix(d)

m




R can store information as an object with a name of our choice

Once we have created an object, we just refer to it by name
we are using objects as “shortcuts” to some piece of information or data

there are many different types (or classes) of objects
arithmetic operations like addition and subtraction cannot be used for character strings
Most obviously, there are actually multiple OOP frameworks in R

S3, S4, R6…
Hadley Wickham’s “Advanced R” provides a very thorough overview of the main ones

But for our purposes, it is much more helpful to think about

the shared characteristics of these different systems and
the broad implications of OOP in R.


What we lose in detail, we hopefully gain in perspective
But do read Hadley’s book if you get the chance + It’s incredibly helpful (as are all his books)

title: R - An Introduction
text:
Object class, type, and structure

Use the class, typeof, and str commands if you want understand more about a particular object




Code
d = data.frame(x = 1:2, y = 3:4) 

class(d) ## Evaluate its class

typeof(d) ## Evaluate its type

str(d) ## Show its structure



we can inspect/print an object directly in the console

e.g. Type d

The View() function is also very helpful

this is the same as clicking on the object in the RStudio Environment pane
e.g. View(d)




PS — Confused by the fact that typeof(d) returns “list”? See here.

title: R - An Introduction
text:
Global environment

The global environment is where all objects are stored

you can see the global environment in the RStudio Environment pane
you can also see the global environment by typing ls() in the console

Working with multiple objects

you can create multiple objects in the global environment
you can manipulate and transform these objects using functions
you can also use the rm() function to remove objects from the global environment

R’s ability to keep multiple objects in memory at the same time is a huge plus when it comes to effective data work

e.g. We can copy an existing data frame, or create new one entirely from scratch - either will exist happily with our existing objects in the global environment





Code
d2 = data.frame(x = rnorm(10), y = runif(10))

title: R - An Introduction
text:
Everything has a name

Every object in R has a name

you can use the name to refer to the object in the global environment
object names are case sensitive

The name of our object must follow certain restrictions

it cannot begin with a number
it should not contain spaces
special characters such as % and $ should not be used

Reserved words

we can assign objects to different names
However, there are a number of special words that are “reserved” in R

These are are fundamental commands, operators and relations in base R that you cannot (re)assign, even if you wanted to
See here for a full list






you can also use the name to refer to the object in a function
function itself is an object

e.g. mean is a function that calculates the mean of a vector
we can assign it to a new name, e.g. average = mean
but we cannot assign it to a reserved word, e.g. if = mean
this will lead to an error

title: R - An Introduction
text:
Everything has a name

Semi-reserved words

there is a class of words and strings that are called “semi-reserved”





Code
my_vector = c(1, 2, 5)
my_vector



what happens if you type the following?





Code
c = 4
c(1, 2 ,5)



R is “smart” enough to distinguish between the variable c = 4 that we created and the built-in function c() that calls for concatenation
However, R won’t always be able to distinguish between conflicting definitions





Code
pi
pi = 2
pi



Bottom line: Don’t use (semi-)reserved characters!



these are named functions or constants (e.g. pi) that you can re-assign if you really wanted to… but already come with important meanings from base R
The c() function is a good example of a semi-reserved character
Arguably the most important semi-reserved character is c(), which we use for concatenation

i.e. creating vectors and binding different objects together

title: R - An Introduction
text:
Namespace conflicts

R has a large number of packages, each with its own set of functions

sometimes, different packages have functions with the same name
this can lead to “namespace conflicts” where R doesn’t know which function to use

e.g. Look what happens we load the dplyr package




Code
library(dplyr)



The messages that you see about some object being masked from ‘package:X’ are warning you about a namespace conflict

e.g. Both dplyr and the stats package have functions named “filter” and “lag”

Whenever a namespace conflict arises, the most recently loaded package will gain preference

so the filter() function now refers specifically to the dplyr variant
what if we want the stats variant?




The potential for namespace conflicts is a result of the OOP approach

Also reflects the fundamental open-source nature of R and the use of external packages
People are free to call their functions whatever they want, so some overlap is only to be expected

Temporarily use stats::filter()

Permanently assign filter = stats::filter

title: R - An Introduction
text:
Namespace conflicts
Two common ways to resolve namespace conflicts in R:

Use package::function()


We can explicitly call a conflicted function from a particular package using the package::function() syntax




Code
stats::filter(1:10, rep(1, 2))






Code
dplyr::starwars ## Print the starwars data frame from the dplyr package

scales::comma(c(1000, 1000000)) ## Use the comma function, which comes from the scales package



Assign function = package::function


A more permanent solution is to assign a conflicted function name to a particular package
This will hold for the remainder of your current R session, or until you change it back





Code
filter = stats::filter ## Note the lack of parentheses
filter = dplyr::filter ## Change it back again





We can also use :: for more than just conflicted cases
e.g. Being explicit about where a function (or dataset) comes from can help add clarity to our code
e.g. dplyr::filter(iris, Species=="virginica") is clearer than just filter(iris, Species=="virginica")

Another good rule of thumb is that you want to load your most important packages last

e.g. Load the tidyverse after you’ve already loaded any other packages

User-side namespace conflicts

A final thing to say about namespace conflicts is that they don’t only arise from loading packages
They can arise when users create their own functions with a conflicting name

e.g. If I was naive enough to create a new function called c()

title: R - An Introduction
text:
Indexing

Indexing is a way to access specific elements of an object

e.g. we can access specific elements of a vector, list, or data frame using indexing

There are two main ways to index objects in R

Option 1: []

This is the most common way to index objects in R
It works for vectors, matrices, data frames, and lists
It can be used to access specific elements of an object, or to subset an object

Option 2: $

This is a special operator that is used to access specific elements of a list or data frame by name
It is often used to access columns of a data frame by name





Indexing is done using square brackets []
Indexing can be done using either numeric or logical vectors

Numeric indexing refers to the position of the element in the object
Logical indexing refers to a logical vector that indicates which elements to keep

Indexing can also be done using names

e.g. we can access specific elements of a data frame using the column names

title: R - An Introduction
text:
Indexing

use [] to index objects that we create in R




Code
a = 1:10
a[4] ## Get the 4th element of object "a"
a[c(4, 6)] ## Get the 4th and 6th elements



It also works on larger arrays (vectors, matrices, data frames, and lists)





Code
library(dplyr)
starwars[1, 1] ## Show the cell corresponding to the 1st row & 1st column of the data frame



What does starwars[1:3, 1] give you?
What does starwars[-1, 1] give you?
what if we want to get the 1st column of the data frame?





Code
starwars[, 1] ## Get the 1st column of the starwars data frame



we can use $ to access the columns of a data frame by name





Code
starwars$name ## Get the "name" column of the starwars data frame




What if you want to get the names of the columns in a data frame? . . .


[1] Indexing in R begins at 1. Not 0 like some languages (e.g. Python and JavaScript)

title: R - An Introduction
text:
Indexing

lists are a more complex type of array object in R

they can contain a random assortment of objects that don’t share the same class

e.g. a list can contain a vector, a data frame, and a matrix
or even lists of lists

lists are very flexible and can be used to store any type of object

The relevance to indexing is that lists require two square brackets [[]] to index the parent list item and then the standard [] within that parent item
This is different from the single square brackets that we use to index vectors, matrices, and data frames

The double square brackets are used to extract the object itself, rather than a subset of the list

title: R - An Introduction
text:
Indexing

Let’s look at an example of a list to see how it works in practice

We’ll use the my_list object, which contains three objects: a character string, a numeric vector, and a data frame

As before, we have two options for indexing lists
Option 1: [[ ]]

use double square brackets to index a list
this will return the object itself, rather than a subset of the list
e.g. my_list[[1]] will return the first object in the list
we can also use my_list[[2]][3] to return the third element of the second object





Code
my_list = list(a = "hello", b = c(1,2,3), c = data.frame(x = 1:5, y = 6:10))

my_list[[1]] 

my_list[[2]][3]

title: R - An Introduction
text:
Indexing

Option 2: $

lists provide a nice segue to our other indexing operator: $
Let’s continue with the my_list example





Code
my_list

my_list$a

my_list$c$x



The $ form of indexing also works (and in the manner that you probably expect) for other object types in R

In some cases, you can also combine the two index options






Code
my_list$b[3]

starwars$name[1]




note some key differences between the output from this example and that of our previous starwars[1, 1] example

What are they?
Hint: Apart from the visual cues, try wrapping each command in str()

The last thing that I want to say about $ is that it provides another way to avoid the “object not found” problem that we ran into with our earlier regression example

e.g. lm(y ~ x) will not work, but lm(d$y ~ d$x) will work


. . .


Code
d = data.frame(x = 1:10, y = 11:20)

lm(y ~ x) 

lm(d$y ~ d$x)

title: R - An Introduction
text:
cleaning up

Use rm() to remove objects from the global environment

e.g. rm(a) will remove the object a from the global environment





Code
a = "hello"
b = "world"
rm(a, b)



use rm(list = ls()) to remove all objects in your working environment (except packages)

Better just to start a new R session




but this is frowned upon



Detaching packages is more complicated

there could be many cross-dependencies (i.e. one package depends on, and might even automatically load, another package)
e.g. detach(package:dplyr)

still, better just to restart your R session

title: R - An Introduction
text:
Removing plots

Use dev.off() to remove the current plot

e.g. dev.off() will remove the current plot from the plotting window

Use graphics.off() to remove all plots




Code
plot(1:10)
dev.off()



RStudio has convenient buttons for clearing your workspace environment and removing (individual) plots

text:

Data files: Loading and saving

R can read and write data files in various formats

e.g. CSV, Excel, SPSS, Stata, etc.
we will focus on CSV files for now

working directory

R will look for files in the current working directory
you can check the current working directory using getwd()
you can change the working directory using setwd()
e.g. setwd("path/to/your/directory")

title: R - An Introduction
text:
Data files: Loading and saving

go to here to download a sample dataset
use read.csv() to read a CSV file into R

e.g. unpop <- read.csv("UNpop.csv")
this will read the CSV file and create a data frame called unpop





Code
unpop <- read.csv("Downloads/UNpop.csv")






Code
class(unpop)



RData can be used to save and load R objects

e.g. save(unpop, file = "unpop.RData") will save the unpop data frame as an RData file
you can load the RData file using load("unpop.RData")

RData files are useful for saving and loading multiple objects at once





Code
save(unpop, file = "unpop.RData")




a data frame is a special type of list where each element is a vector of the same length

data frames are used to store tabular data, where each column represents a variable and each row represents an observation

R will save the entire workspace as .RData in the working directory without an explicit file name and automatically load it next time we launch

This is not recommended practice because the .RData file is invisible to users of many operating systems and R will not tell us what objects are loaded unless we explicitly issue the ls() function

title: R - An Introduction
text:

useful functions for exploring data frames

names() to view the names of the columns in a data frame

Boxplots and related plots

Boxplots, violin and jittered points are useful for visualizing the distribution of a continuous variable



Code
##| layout-ncol: 3
##| fig-width: 4

library(ggpubr)

jitter<- ggplot(mpg, aes(drv, hwy)) + geom_jitter()
boxplot<- ggplot(mpg, aes(drv, hwy)) + geom_boxplot()
violin<- ggplot(mpg, aes(drv, hwy)) + geom_violin()

ggarrange(jitter, boxplot, violin, ncol=3)











A boxplot is a type of visual shorthand for measures of position (percentiles) that describe a distribution

It is also useful for identifying potential outliers in the data
Visual points that display observations that fall more than 1.5 times the IQR from either edge of the box
These outlying points are unusual so are plotted individually

A violin plot is a combination of a boxplot and a kernel density plot

It shows the distribution of the data, the median, and the interquartile range
It is useful for comparing the distribution of a continuous variable across different categories

A jittered point plot is useful for visualizing the distribution of a continuous variable across different categories

It is useful for identifying potential outliers in the data

The first step in any data analysis is to load the data into R

the data can be in a variety of formats
the most common formats are CSV, Excel, and SPSS

Here are some details about the dataset

The National Longitudinal Study of Adolescent to Adult Health (Add Health)
a longitudinal study of a nationally representative sample of adolescents in grades 7-12 in the United States during the 1994-95 school year (Wave I)
The Add Health cohort has been followed into young adulthood with four in-home interviews for Wave I-IV by 2008

the Wave V conducted during 2016-2018 included a mixed-mode survey

respondents’ social, economic, psychological, and physical well-being

along with contextual data on the family, neighborhood, community, school, friendships, peer groups, and romantic relationships

study developmental trajectories of health and risk behaviors throughout the life course






The dataset used here is a subset of the Add Health dataset

The National Longitudinal Study of Adolescent to Adult Health (Add Health)
a longitudinal study of a nationally representative sample of adolescents in grades 7-12 in the United States during the 1994-95 school year (Wave I)
The Add Health cohort has been followed into young adulthood with four in-home interviews for Wave I-IV by 2008

study developmental trajectories of health and risk behaviors throughout the life course

title: Data Wrangling with R
text:
For loops

The for loop is the most common type of loop in R

it repeats a block of code a specified number of times
it can go through every element of a vector

syntax: for (i in vector) {code to execute}


it can iterate through a set number of elements in a vector

syntax: for (i in 1:length(vector)) {code to execute}


The for loop is also useful for:

creating new variables
running simulations




Steps to turn into a for loop:

Initialize a vector to store results- this time it will store an entire vector of results rather than one result. Can either do: 1.1 Initialize a vector of a certain length: vec <- vector(length = desired length) 1.2 Initialize an empty vector: vec <- c()
Use the for statement to tell the loop what to iterate through.
Copy and paste the code from the single-observation case into the “meat” part of the for loop sandwich
For step three, make sure to add indexing where appropriate

title: Data Wrangling with R
text:
Tidy approach to data

The tidy approach (Wickham (2014)) to data is a way to organize data in a consistent format

each variable is a column
each observation is a row
each type of observational unit is a table
each value is a cell




Five common problems for messy data

Column headers are values, not variable names
Multiple variables are stored in one column
Variables are stored in both rows and columns
Multiple types of observational units are stored in the same table
A single observational unit is stored in multiple tables

Export data

The last step in data analysis is to export the data

save the data in a format that can be shared with others
save the data in a format that can be read by other software
save the data in a format that can be used in other software

text:
Basic merge

The typical merge in R is left_join

keep all rows from “left” table even if observation doesn’t have matching row in “right” table
this will drop observations from the joining data when they are not matched to the “left” table




Code
sleep_tidy<- tibble(name=c("KT", "Olivia", "Dean", "May", "Mary"),

title: R - An Introduction
text:
Introduction

R is a programming language and software environment for statistical computing and graphics

widely used in academia and industry
for data analysis, statistical modeling, and visualization
for machine learning, data mining, and big data analysis
for reproducible research and scientific computing

R is an implementation of the S programming language

S was developed at Bell Laboratories by John Chambers and colleagues
S was designed for data analysis and graphics
S was the precursor to the commercial statistical software package S-PLUS

title: R - An Introduction
text:
Introduction

R was created by Ross Ihaka and Robert Gentleman at the University of Auckland, New Zealand

named partly after the first names of the first two R authors and partly as a play on the name of S
a GNU project, a free software movement initiated by Richard Stallman in 1983
freely available under the GNU General Public License
a large number of packages available

title: R - An Introduction
text:
Introduction

tidyverse is a collection of R packages designed for data science

tidyverse packages share an underlying design philosophy, grammar, and data structures
tidyverse packages are designed to work together

focus on the tidyverse

mainly because it is easier to understand
do most data manipulation we need in social science research with these tools

A good reference for tidyverse is the book by Wickham (2019)

R for Data Science

title: R - An Introduction
text:
Introduction

for quick reference, visit Posit Primers on Data Science

R Basics
Transform Tables
Visualize Data

for more specific topics, visit Data Science

Data Wrangling
Data Visualization
Modelling

we use cover some base R functions first, then move on to the tidyverse

title: R - An Introduction
text:
Basic Arithmetic

R can be regarded as a calculator

it recognizes all of the standard arithmetic operators





Code
# Basic arithmetic operations in R

1+2 

6-7 

5/2 

2^3

2+5*2^3

3*(4+5) 

(3+4)*5

sqrt(4)



modulo operators (integer division & remainder)





Code
# Modulo operators in R

5 %/% 2  # integer division
5 %% 2   # remainder

100 %/% 60 ## How many whole hours in 100 minutes?

100 %% 60 ## How many minutes are left over?




In RStudio, you can start a new script using the dropdown menu File > New File > R Script
use your R script to save finalized commands

type in the console to practice and debug, then use the script to save what worked

R scripts allow you to save comments, or annotations, to your code

anything following the # symbol in a script will not be treated like an R command—essentially, R will skip over it

title: R - An Introduction
text:
Logic

R can also be used for logical operations

it recognizes the standard logical operators





Code
1 > 2

1 > 2 & 1 > 0.5 # The "&" stands for "and"

1 > 2 | 1 > 0.5 # The "|" stands for "or" (not a pipe a la the shell)

isTRUE (1 < 2)



Here are the detailed list of logical operators in R

& and | are used for element-wise logical operations
&& and || are used for short-circuit logical operations

e.g. 1 > 2 && 1 > 0.5 will return FALSE without evaluating the second condition

! is used for negation (i.e. “not”)
==, !=, <, <=, >, and >= are used for comparison

Here is further information about logical vectors in R

Logical vectors are vectors that contain only TRUE, FALSE, or NA values
Logical vectors are often used for subsetting data frames or matrices

title: R - An Introduction
text:
Logic

Order of precedence

logic statements follow a strict order of precedence
logical operators (>, ==, etc) are evaluated before Boolean operators (& and |)

failure to recognise this can lead to unexpected behaviour






Code
1 > 0.5 & 2






Code
1 > 0.5 & 1 > 2



Lesson: explicit about each component of your logic statement(s)



2 is converted into as.logical(2)
as.logical(2) is TRUE because it is not zero



Negation: !

this will come in very handy when we start filtering data objects






Code
is.na(1:10)
!is.na(1:10)

Negate(is.na)(1:10)

title: R - An Introduction
text:
logical operators

Value matching: %in%

whether an object is contained within (i.e. matches one of) a list of items, use %in%





Code
4 %in% 1:10

4 %in% 5:10



There’s no equivalent “not in” command

but we can create one






Code
`%ni%` = Negate(`%in%`) ## The backticks (`) help to specify functions.

4 %ni% 5:10



Evaluation

use two equal signs for logical evaluation






Code
1 == 1 ## This does.

1 != 2 ## Note the single equal sign when combined with a negation




Evaluation caveat: Floating-point numbers
What do you think will happen if we evaluate 0.1 + 0.2 == 0.3?
0.1 + 0.2 == 0.3
Problem: Computers represent numbers as binary (i.e. base 2) floating-points

More here.

Fast and memory efficient, but can lead to unexpected behaviour.


Similar to the way that standard decimal (i.e. base 10) representation can’t precisely capture certain fractions

e.g. \(\frac{1}{3} = 0.3333...\)

Solution: Use all.equal() for evaluating floats (i.e fractions)

all.equal(0.1 + 0.2, 0.3)

title: R - An Introduction
text:
Assignment operators

Assignment: <- or =

use <- for assignment, but = is also acceptable
<- is the preferred operator in R, but = is more common in other programming languages





Code
a <- 10 + 5
a



nevertheless, we can use = for assignment





Code
b = 10 + 10 

b




an arrow can point in the other direction too (i.e. ->)
the following code chunk is equivalent to the previous one, although used much less frequently



Code
10 + 5 -> a



Note that the assigned object must be on the left with “=”

title: R - An Introduction
text:
Help

Use help or ? to get help on a function

e.g. ?mean will give you the documentation for the mean() function

For more information on a (named) function or object in R, consult the “help” documentation. For example:




Code
help(plot)

?plot 



Comments in R are demarcated by #.
Hit Ctrl+Shift+c in RStudio to (un)comment whole sections of highlighted code
Vignettes

for many packages, you can also try the vignette() function, which will provide an introduction to a package and it’s purpose through a series of helpful examples

e.g. vignette("ggplot2") will give you a detailed introduction to the ggplot2 package





see the Examples section at the bottom of the help file?

You can run them with the example() function
Try it: example(plot)

title: R - An Introduction
text:
Object-oriented programming (OOP) in R

R is an object-oriented programming language

everything in R is an object
objects can be manipulated and transformed using functions
functions are also objects in R

R has three main object classes

vectors
lists
data frames

R also has other object classes, such as matrices, arrays, and factors
Each object class has its own set of rules (“methods”) for determining valid operations

e.g. you can perform many of the same operations on matrices and data frames
But there are some operations that only work on a matrix, and vice versa
At the same time, you can (usually) convert an object from one type to another





Code
## Create a small data frame called "d".

d = data.frame(x = 1:2, y = 3:4) 

d






Code
## Convert it to (i.e. create) a matrix call "m".

m = as.matrix(d)

m




R can store information as an object with a name of our choice

Once we have created an object, we just refer to it by name
we are using objects as “shortcuts” to some piece of information or data

there are many different types (or classes) of objects
arithmetic operations like addition and subtraction cannot be used for character strings
Most obviously, there are actually multiple OOP frameworks in R

S3, S4, R6…
Hadley Wickham’s “Advanced R” provides a very thorough overview of the main ones

But for our purposes, it is much more helpful to think about

the shared characteristics of these different systems and
the broad implications of OOP in R.


What we lose in detail, we hopefully gain in perspective
But do read Hadley’s book if you get the chance + It’s incredibly helpful (as are all his books)

title: R - An Introduction
text:
Object class, type, and structure

Use the class, typeof, and str commands if you want understand more about a particular object




Code
d = data.frame(x = 1:2, y = 3:4) 

class(d) ## Evaluate its class

typeof(d) ## Evaluate its type

str(d) ## Show its structure



we can inspect/print an object directly in the console

e.g. Type d

The View() function is also very helpful

this is the same as clicking on the object in the RStudio Environment pane
e.g. View(d)




PS — Confused by the fact that typeof(d) returns “list”? See here.

title: R - An Introduction
text:
Global environment

The global environment is where all objects are stored

you can see the global environment in the RStudio Environment pane
you can also see the global environment by typing ls() in the console

Working with multiple objects

you can create multiple objects in the global environment
you can manipulate and transform these objects using functions
you can also use the rm() function to remove objects from the global environment

R’s ability to keep multiple objects in memory at the same time is a huge plus when it comes to effective data work

e.g. We can copy an existing data frame, or create new one entirely from scratch - either will exist happily with our existing objects in the global environment





Code
d2 = data.frame(x = rnorm(10), y = runif(10))

title: R - An Introduction
text:
Everything has a name

Every object in R has a name

you can use the name to refer to the object in the global environment
object names are case sensitive

The name of our object must follow certain restrictions

it cannot begin with a number
it should not contain spaces
special characters such as % and $ should not be used

Reserved words

we can assign objects to different names
However, there are a number of special words that are “reserved” in R

These are are fundamental commands, operators and relations in base R that you cannot (re)assign, even if you wanted to
See here for a full list






you can also use the name to refer to the object in a function
function itself is an object

e.g. mean is a function that calculates the mean of a vector
we can assign it to a new name, e.g. average = mean
but we cannot assign it to a reserved word, e.g. if = mean
this will lead to an error

title: R - An Introduction
text:
Everything has a name

Semi-reserved words

there is a class of words and strings that are called “semi-reserved”





Code
my_vector = c(1, 2, 5)
my_vector



what happens if you type the following?





Code
c = 4
c(1, 2 ,5)



R is “smart” enough to distinguish between the variable c = 4 that we created and the built-in function c() that calls for concatenation
However, R won’t always be able to distinguish between conflicting definitions





Code
pi
pi = 2
pi



Bottom line: Don’t use (semi-)reserved characters!



these are named functions or constants (e.g. pi) that you can re-assign if you really wanted to… but already come with important meanings from base R
The c() function is a good example of a semi-reserved character
Arguably the most important semi-reserved character is c(), which we use for concatenation

i.e. creating vectors and binding different objects together

title: R - An Introduction
text:
Namespace conflicts

R has a large number of packages, each with its own set of functions

sometimes, different packages have functions with the same name
this can lead to “namespace conflicts” where R doesn’t know which function to use

e.g. Look what happens we load the dplyr package




Code
library(dplyr)



The messages that you see about some object being masked from ‘package:X’ are warning you about a namespace conflict

e.g. Both dplyr and the stats package have functions named “filter” and “lag”

Whenever a namespace conflict arises, the most recently loaded package will gain preference

so the filter() function now refers specifically to the dplyr variant
what if we want the stats variant?




The potential for namespace conflicts is a result of the OOP approach

Also reflects the fundamental open-source nature of R and the use of external packages
People are free to call their functions whatever they want, so some overlap is only to be expected

Temporarily use stats::filter()

Permanently assign filter = stats::filter

title: R - An Introduction
text:
Namespace conflicts
Two common ways to resolve namespace conflicts in R:

Use package::function()


We can explicitly call a conflicted function from a particular package using the package::function() syntax




Code
stats::filter(1:10, rep(1, 2))






Code
dplyr::starwars ## Print the starwars data frame from the dplyr package

scales::comma(c(1000, 1000000)) ## Use the comma function, which comes from the scales package



Assign function = package::function


A more permanent solution is to assign a conflicted function name to a particular package
This will hold for the remainder of your current R session, or until you change it back





Code
filter = stats::filter ## Note the lack of parentheses
filter = dplyr::filter ## Change it back again





We can also use :: for more than just conflicted cases
e.g. Being explicit about where a function (or dataset) comes from can help add clarity to our code
e.g. dplyr::filter(iris, Species=="virginica") is clearer than just filter(iris, Species=="virginica")

Another good rule of thumb is that you want to load your most important packages last

e.g. Load the tidyverse after you’ve already loaded any other packages

User-side namespace conflicts

A final thing to say about namespace conflicts is that they don’t only arise from loading packages
They can arise when users create their own functions with a conflicting name

e.g. If I was naive enough to create a new function called c()

title: R - An Introduction
text:
Indexing

Indexing is a way to access specific elements of an object

e.g. we can access specific elements of a vector, list, or data frame using indexing

There are two main ways to index objects in R

Option 1: []

This is the most common way to index objects in R
It works for vectors, matrices, data frames, and lists
It can be used to access specific elements of an object, or to subset an object

Option 2: $

This is a special operator that is used to access specific elements of a list or data frame by name
It is often used to access columns of a data frame by name





Indexing is done using square brackets []
Indexing can be done using either numeric or logical vectors

Numeric indexing refers to the position of the element in the object
Logical indexing refers to a logical vector that indicates which elements to keep

Indexing can also be done using names

e.g. we can access specific elements of a data frame using the column names

title: R - An Introduction
text:
Indexing

use [] to index objects that we create in R




Code
a = 1:10
a[4] ## Get the 4th element of object "a"
a[c(4, 6)] ## Get the 4th and 6th elements



It also works on larger arrays (vectors, matrices, data frames, and lists)





Code
library(dplyr)
starwars[1, 1] ## Show the cell corresponding to the 1st row & 1st column of the data frame



What does starwars[1:3, 1] give you?
What does starwars[-1, 1] give you?
what if we want to get the 1st column of the data frame?





Code
starwars[, 1] ## Get the 1st column of the starwars data frame



we can use $ to access the columns of a data frame by name





Code
starwars$name ## Get the "name" column of the starwars data frame




What if you want to get the names of the columns in a data frame? . . .


[1] Indexing in R begins at 1. Not 0 like some languages (e.g. Python and JavaScript)

title: R - An Introduction
text:
Indexing

lists are a more complex type of array object in R

they can contain a random assortment of objects that don’t share the same class

e.g. a list can contain a vector, a data frame, and a matrix
or even lists of lists

lists are very flexible and can be used to store any type of object

The relevance to indexing is that lists require two square brackets [[]] to index the parent list item and then the standard [] within that parent item
This is different from the single square brackets that we use to index vectors, matrices, and data frames

The double square brackets are used to extract the object itself, rather than a subset of the list

title: R - An Introduction
text:
Indexing

Let’s look at an example of a list to see how it works in practice

We’ll use the my_list object, which contains three objects: a character string, a numeric vector, and a data frame

As before, we have two options for indexing lists
Option 1: [[ ]]

use double square brackets to index a list
this will return the object itself, rather than a subset of the list
e.g. my_list[[1]] will return the first object in the list
we can also use my_list[[2]][3] to return the third element of the second object





Code
my_list = list(a = "hello", b = c(1,2,3), c = data.frame(x = 1:5, y = 6:10))

my_list[[1]] 

my_list[[2]][3]

title: R - An Introduction
text:
Indexing

Option 2: $

lists provide a nice segue to our other indexing operator: $
Let’s continue with the my_list example





Code
my_list

my_list$a

my_list$c$x



The $ form of indexing also works (and in the manner that you probably expect) for other object types in R

In some cases, you can also combine the two index options






Code
my_list$b[3]

starwars$name[1]




note some key differences between the output from this example and that of our previous starwars[1, 1] example

What are they?
Hint: Apart from the visual cues, try wrapping each command in str()

The last thing that I want to say about $ is that it provides another way to avoid the “object not found” problem that we ran into with our earlier regression example

e.g. lm(y ~ x) will not work, but lm(d$y ~ d$x) will work


. . .


Code
d = data.frame(x = 1:10, y = 11:20)

lm(y ~ x) 

lm(d$y ~ d$x)

title: R - An Introduction
text:
cleaning up

Use rm() to remove objects from the global environment

e.g. rm(a) will remove the object a from the global environment





Code
a = "hello"
b = "world"
rm(a, b)



use rm(list = ls()) to remove all objects in your working environment (except packages)

Better just to start a new R session




but this is frowned upon



Detaching packages is more complicated

there could be many cross-dependencies (i.e. one package depends on, and might even automatically load, another package)
e.g. detach(package:dplyr)

still, better just to restart your R session

title: R - An Introduction
text:
Removing plots

Use dev.off() to remove the current plot

e.g. dev.off() will remove the current plot from the plotting window

Use graphics.off() to remove all plots




Code
plot(1:10)
dev.off()



RStudio has convenient buttons for clearing your workspace environment and removing (individual) plots

title: R - An Introduction
text:
Data files: Loading and saving

R can read and write data files in various formats

e.g. CSV, Excel, SPSS, Stata, etc.
we will focus on CSV files for now

working directory

R will look for files in the current working directory
you can check the current working directory using getwd()
you can change the working directory using setwd()
e.g. setwd("path/to/your/directory")

title: R - An Introduction
text:
Data files: Loading and saving

go to here to download a sample dataset
use read.csv() to read a CSV file into R

e.g. unpop <- read.csv("UNpop.csv")
this will read the CSV file and create a data frame called unpop





Code
unpop <- read.csv("Downloads/UNpop.csv")






Code
class(unpop)



RData can be used to save and load R objects

e.g. save(unpop, file = "unpop.RData") will save the unpop data frame as an RData file
you can load the RData file using load("unpop.RData")

RData files are useful for saving and loading multiple objects at once





Code
save(unpop, file = "unpop.RData")




a data frame is a special type of list where each element is a vector of the same length

data frames are used to store tabular data, where each column represents a variable and each row represents an observation

R will save the entire workspace as .RData in the working directory without an explicit file name and automatically load it next time we launch

Statistics

Facets

This is useful for comparing different groups or categories within the data

top5_partners=c("China", "Denmark", "Canada", "Hong Kong, China", "Switzerland")

options(scipen = 999)

library(ggthemes)
library(scales)
library(plotly)

p <- toy_imports %>% 
  filter(partner_name %in% top5_partners) %>%
  group_by(year, partner_name) %>%
  summarize(total_import=sum(US_report_import)) %>% 
  ggplot(aes(year, total_import, color=partner_name)) +

  labs(title="Toy imports from the U.S.'s top-5 partners, 1996-2005",
       x="Year",
       y="Dollar value of imports (log scale)",
       color="Import Region")+
  scale_x_continuous(breaks=1996:2005)+
  scale_y_log10(

    labels = trans_format("log10", math_format(.x))) +

  theme_economist()+

text:
ggplot2 — Boxplots and related plots

Boxplots, violin and jittered points are useful for visualizing the distribution of a continuous variable



Code
library(ggpubr)

boxplot<- ggplot(mpg, 
                 aes(drv, hwy)) +
  geom_boxplot()

violin<- ggplot(mpg, 
                aes(drv, hwy)) + geom_violin()


jitter<- ggplot(mpg, 
                aes(drv, hwy)) +
  geom_jitter()

ggarrange(boxplot, violin, jitter,  ncol=3)













A boxplot is a type of visual shorthand for measures of position (percentiles) that describe a distribution

It is also useful for identifying potential outliers in the data
Visual points that display observations that fall more than 1.5 times the IQR from either edge of the box
These outlying points are unusual so are plotted individually

A violin plot is a combination of a boxplot and a kernel density plot

It shows the distribution of the data, the median, and the interquartile range
It is useful for comparing the distribution of a continuous variable across different categories

A jittered point plot is useful for visualizing the distribution of a continuous variable across different categories

It is useful for identifying potential outliers in the data

The National Longitudinal Study of Adolescent to Adult Health (Add Health)
a longitudinal study of a nationally representative sample of adolescents in grades 7-12 in the United States during the 1994-95 school year (Wave I)

title: Data Wrangling with R
text:
For loops

The for loop is the most common type of loop in R

it repeats a block of code a specified number of times
it can go through every element of a vector

syntax: for (i in vector) {code to execute}


it can iterate through a set number of elements in a vector

syntax: for (i in 1:length(vector)) {code to execute}


The for loop is also useful for:

creating new variables
running simulations




Steps to turn into a for loop:

Initialize a vector to store results- this time it will store an entire vector of results rather than one result. Can either do: 1.1 Initialize a vector of a certain length: vec <- vector(length = desired length) 1.2 Initialize an empty vector: vec <- c()
Use the for statement to tell the loop what to iterate through.
Copy and paste the code from the single-observation case into the “meat” part of the for loop sandwich
For step three, make sure to add indexing where appropriate

title: Data Wrangling with R

Tidy approach to data

The tidy approach (Wickham (2014)) to data is a way to organize data in a consistent format

Each variable is a column; each column is a variable
Each observation is a row; each row is an observation
Each value is a cell; each cell is a single value

The tidy approach is useful for:

data manipulation
data visualization
data analysis
data sharing

The tidy approach is implemented in the tidyr package



The tidy approach is a way to organize data in a consistent format

it is based on the idea that data should be organized in a way that makes it easy to manipulate, visualize, and analyze
it is a way to make data more accessible and easier to work with

Five common problems for messy data

Column headers are values, not variable names
Multiple variables are stored in one column
Variables are stored in both rows and columns
Multiple types of observational units are stored in the same table
A single observational unit is stored in multiple tables

title: Probability and Distribution
text:
Motivation

in many cases we must figure out ways to distinguish systematic patterns from noise
Probability is a set of mathematical tools that measure and model randomness in the world
in social sciences, we use probability to model the randomly determined nature of various realworld events as well as human behavior and beliefs

our task is to identify systematic patterns from apparently noisy data

we use probability to quantify the degree of uncertainty about empirical findings



Quantifying the degree of statistical uncertainty about empirical findings
Noise, also known as random error, is the irrelevant variation that occurs in every realworld data set
Randomness does not necessarily imply complete unpredictability

title: Probability and Distribution
section: Two schools of thought in probability
text:
Two schools of thought in probability

Frequentist

probability represents the limit of the relative frequency

the ratio between the number of times the event occurs and the number of trials, in repeated trials under the same conditions

objective interpretation of probability
assumes that all outcomes are equally likely

Bayesian

probability is a measure of one’s subjective belief or certainty about the likelihood of event occurrence
named after a eighteenth century English mathematician and minister, Thomas Bayes

Probability was established as a mathematical theory by Russian mathematician Andrey Kolmogorov in the early twentieth century

Kolmogorov’s axioms of probability provide a mathematical foundation for both frequentist and Bayesian interpretations




under the Bayesian framework, probability simply becomes a tool to describe one’s belief system rather than real-world phenomena
Frequentist: probability is the long-run relative frequency of an event occurring in repeated trials
Bayesian: probability is a measure of one’s subjective belief about the likelihood of event occurrence
Kolmogorov’s axioms of probability provide a mathematical foundation for both frequentist and Bayesian interpretations
Kolmogorov’s axioms are a set of three rules that define the properties of probability measures
Kolmogorov’s work established probability theory as a rigorous mathematical discipline, providing a framework for both frequentist and Bayesian approaches

title: Probability and Distribution
text:
Deinfition of Probability

The definition of probability involves three concepts

experiment: an action or a set of actions that produce stochastic events of interest
sample space: a set of all possible outcomes of the experiment, typically denoted by \(\Omega\)
event: a subset of the sample space

An event represents any subset of sample space

it may include multiple outcomes
the entire sample space that contains all outcomes is also an event
an event occurs if the set that defines the event includes an actual outcome of the experiment

the probability of event \(A\) occurring, denoted by \(P(A)\), can be computed as the ratio of the number of elements in the corresponding set \(A\) to that in the entire sample space \(\Omega\)


\[
P(A) = \frac{\text{number of elements in } A}{\text{number of elements in } \Omega}
\]


an experiment of tossing a fair coin three times
When each outcome is equally likely, in order to compute the probability of event A

we need to count the number of elements in the event A, as well as the total number of elements in the sample space 

title: Probability and Distribution
text:
Axioms of Probability

The probability axioms are given by the three rules below

The probability of any event A is nonnegative: \(P(A) ≥ 0\)
The probability that one of the outcomes in the sample space occurs is 1: \(P(\Omega)= 1\)
If events A and B are mutually exclusive, then \(P(A \textrm{ or } B) = P(A) + P(B)\)

For any given events A and B, the addition rule is given by \(P(A \textrm{ or } B) = P(A) + P(B) − P(A \textrm{ and } B)\)
the complement of a set - all elements in the sample space except those in the set

the complement of event A is denoted by \(A^c\), and its probability is given by \(P(A^c) = 1 - P(A)\)
e.g the complement of the event \({A \textrm{ or } B}\) is \({A^c \textrm{ and } B^c}\)

For any given events A and B, the law of total probability is given by


\[
P(A) = P(A \textrm{ and } B) + P(A \textrm{ and } B^c)
\]


The first two axioms together imply that probability ranges from 0 to 1
“Mutually exclusive” in the last axiom means that two events A and B do not share an outcome

Using the Venn diagram, mutually exclusive events imply two disjoint sets, which do not share any element

decompose the event \({A \textrm{ or } B\) into three mutually exclusive events

\({A \textrm{ and } B^c}\), \({A^c \textrm{ and } B}\), and \({A \textrm{ and } B}\)

title: Probability and Distribution
text:
Permutations

Permutation is an arrangement of objects in a specific order
e.g. the number of ways to arrange three objects A, B, and C is \(6\)

\(ABC, ACB, BAC, BCA, CAB, CBA\)

the number of permutations of n objects is given by n! (n factorial)
the factorial of a non-negative integer \(n\) is the product of all positive integers less than or equal to \(n\)

\(n! = n \times (n-1) \times (n-2) \times ... \times 3 \times 2 \times 1\)
e.g. \(3! = 3 \times 2 \times 1 = 6\)

the factorial of 0 is defined as 1, i.e. \(0! = 1\)
The number of permutations when arranging \(k\) objects out of \(n\) unique objects is given by \(_nP_k=\frac{n!}{(n-k)!}\)
e.g. the number of ways in which you can arrange 4 cards out of 13 unique cards

\(_{13}P_4 = \frac{13!}{(13-4)!} = \frac{13!}{9!} = 13 \times 12 \times 11 \times 10 = 17160\)




Permutations refers to the number of ways in which objects can be arranged

the order of arrangement matters
e.g. the number of ways to arrange three objects A, B, and C is 6

ABC, ACB, BAC, BCA, CAB, CBA

title: Probability and Distribution
Probability and Distribution
text:
Sampling with and without replacement

The Monte Carlo simulation method

a general class of stochastic methods that can be used to approximately solve analytical problems by randomly generating quantities of interest

For the birthday problem, we sample \(k\) possibly nonunique birthdays out of 365 days and check whether or not the sampled \(k\) birthdays are all different

this is called sampling with replacement
for each of \(k\) draws, every one of 365 days is equally likely to be sampled regardless of which dates were sampled before





Code
set.seed(123) # for reproducibility
k<-23

n_trials <- 10000 # number of simulation trials
event<- 0

for (i in 1:n_trials) {
  # sample k birthdays with replacement
  birthdays <- sample(1:365, k, replace = TRUE)
  
  # check if there are any duplicates
  if (length(unique(birthdays)) < k) {
    event <- event + 1
  }
}

# compute the probability
probability <- event / n_trials

print(probability)







repeating this sampling procedure many times, we compute the fraction of simulation trials where at least two birthdays are the same, and this fraction serves as an estimate of the corresponding probability
This difference (from 0.507) is called the Monte Carlo error, which is an inevitable consequence of the simulation approach

The size of the Monte Carlo error depends on the nature of the problem
It is difficult to eliminate such an error but possible to reduce it
To obtain a more accurate estimate, we increase the number of simulations

title: Probability and Distribution
text:
Combinations

combinations refers to the number of ways to choose \(k\) distinct elements out of \(n\) elements without regard to their order
two different permutations AB and BA represent an identical combination
e.g. choose \(2\) distinct elements out of \(3\) elements A, B, and C

the number of permutations is \(_3P_2 = 6\)
the number of combinations is \(3\)

The number of combinations when choosing \(k\) distinct elements from \(n\) elements is denoted by \({n \choose k}\)


\[
{n \choose k} = \frac{n!}{k!(n-k)!}
\]

e.g. Suppose that we are creating a committee of 5 out of 20 people (10 men and 10 women), assuming that each person is equally likely to be assigned to the committee

What is the probability that at least 2 women are on the committee?




P(at least 2 women are on the committee)= = 1 − P(no woman is on the committee) − P(exactly one woman is on the committee)

title: Probability and Distribution
text:
Conditonal Probability

Conditional Probability concerns how the probability of an event changes after we observe other events

enables us to take into account observed evidence

The conditional probability of event A occurring given that event B occurred is defined as


\[
P(A|B)= \frac{P(A \textrm{ and B})}{P(B)}
\]

where \(P(A \textrm{ and B})\) is the joint probability of events A and B occurring together, and \(P(B)\) is the marginal probability of event B occurring

title: Probability and Distribution
text:
Conditonal Probability

We can also express the joint probability of events A and B in terms of conditional probabilities


\[
P(A \textrm{ and } B) = P(A|B) \cdot P(B) = P(B|A) \cdot P(A)
\]

we can write the law of total probability in terms of conditional probabilities



\[
P(A) = P(A|B) \cdot P(B) + P(A|B^c) \cdot P(B^c)
\]

title: Probability and Distribution
text:
Conditonal Probability - Example 1

consider two couples who are expecting twins

One couple had an ultrasound exam but the technician was only able to determine that one of the two children was a boy
The other couple did not find out the sex of their twins until the delivery, when they saw the first baby was a boy

Question: What is the probability that both babies are boys?



the sample space = \(\{GG, GB, BG, BB\}\)

e.g. \(GB\) means that the elder twin is a girl and the younger one is a boy

\(P(BB| \textrm{ at least one is a boy }=\frac{P(BB)}{P(BB \text{ or } BG \textrm{ or } GB)}=\frac{1}{3}\)
\(P(BB | \textrm{ elder twin is a boy } = \frac{P(BB)}{P(BB \textrm{ or } BG)}=\frac{1}{2}\)

title: Probability and Distribution
text:
Conditonal Probability - Example 2

compute the joint probability of race and gender




Code
joint_p <- voters %>% 
  count(gender, race) %>% 
  mutate(prop = n / sum(n))

joint_p



Question: compute the probability of being an African American voter





Code
joint_p_wider<- joint_p %>% 
  select(-n) %>% 
  pivot_wider(names_from = gender,
              values_from = prop) %>% 
  mutate(total_prop=f+m)

joint_p_wider



Question: computer the marginal probability of gender





Code
joint_p_wider<- joint_p %>% 
  select(-n) %>% 
  pivot_wider(names_from=race,
              values_from=prop) %>% 
  mutate(total_prop=rowSums(across(where(is.numeric))))

joint_p_wider

Code

  group_by(gender) %>% 
  summarise(prop =sum(prop))




This joint probability gives \(P\)(black and female) = 0.07 and \(P\)(white and male) = 0.32

From this joint probability, we can compute the marginal and conditional probabilities

to obtain the marginal probability we apply the law of total probability

\(P(\textrm{black})=P(\textrm{black and female}) + P(\textrm{black and male})\)

summing over gender columns for each racial row results in the marginal probability of race
To save us from having to type out the names of each race column in the mutate() function to create the total_prop variable

we use the rowSums() function with additional helper functions
The where() function allows us to select columns that match the specified criteria—here we select all the variables that are numeric
The across() function applies a transformation over a series of columns
In short, the rowSums(across(where(is.numeric))) portion of the code tells R to sum the values of all the columns that are numeric

title: Probability and Distribution
text:
Independence

the independence of two events implies that knowledge of one event does not give us any additional information about the occurrence of the other event
Two events A and B are independent if and only if


\[
P(A|B) = P(A) \textrm{ and } P(B|A) = P(B)
\]

Equivalently, two events A and B are independent if and only if



\[
P(A \textrm{ and } B) = P(A) \cdot P(B)
\]

title: Probability and Distribution
text:
Independence

title: Probability and Distribution
text:
Bayes’ rule

Bayes’ rule shows how updating beliefs after observing some data
Bayes’ rule is a fundamental theorem of probability that relates the conditional and marginal probabilities of random events
Bayes’ rule is given by


\[
P(A|B) = \frac{P(B|A) \cdot P(A)}{P(B)}
\]

\(P(A)\) is called the prior probability and reflects one’s initial belief about the likelihood of event A occurring
After observing the data, represented as event B, we update our belief and obtain \(P(A | B)\), which is called the posterior probability

title: Probability and Distribution
text:
Example — Monty Hall Game

The Monty Hall problem is a famous probability puzzle based on a game show scenario

named after the original host of the American television game show Let’s Make a Deal, Monty Hall

The game involves three doors, behind one of which is a car (the prize), and behind the other two are goats (not the prize)
The contestant chooses one door, then the host, who knows where the car is, opens one of the other two doors to reveal a goat

The contestant is then given the option to either stick with their original choice or switch to the other unopened door





Code
# create a function that simulates the game
sims <- 10000
doors <- c("goat", "goat", "car")
result.switch <- result.noswitch <- rep(NA, sims)

for (i in 1:sims) {
  ## randomly choose the initial door
  first <- sample(1:3, size = 1)
  result.noswitch[i] <- doors[first]
  remain <- doors[-first] # remaining two doors
  ## Monty chooses one door with a goat
  if (doors[first] == "car") # two goats left
    monty <- sample(1:2, size = 1)
  else # one goat and one car left
    monty <- (1:2)[remain == "goat"]
  result.switch[i] <- remain[-monty]
  }

mean(result.noswitch == "car")

mean(result.switch == "car")

title: Probability and Distribution
section: Predicting race using surname and residence location
text:
Predicting race using surname and residence location

infer certain unknown attributes of individuals from their known characteristics

here, we consider the problem of predicting individual race using surname and residence location
Accurate prediction of individual race is useful when studying turnout rates among racial groups

The US Census Bureau releases a list of common surnames with their frequency
The data set includes a total of more than 150000 surnames that occurred at least 100 times

the census provides the relative frequencies of individual race within each surname using a six-category self-reported race measure

non-Hispanic White, non-Hispanic African American, non-Hispanic Asian and Pacific Islander, Hispanic origin, non-Hispanic American Indian and Alaskan Native, and non-Hispanic of two or more races

in the following analysis, we combine the last two categories into a single category of non-Hispanic others, so that we have five categories in total






The self-reported information, which can be written as \(P(race | surname)\), enables us to predict race given an individual’s surname
Note that \(P(race)\), \(P(race | surname)\), and \(P(\textrm{race and surname})\) are examples of general ways to represent the marginal, conditional, and joint probabilities, respectively

title: Probability and Distribution
section: Predicting race using surname and residence location
text:
Predicting race using surname and residence location

improve the above prediction by taking into account where voters live

there exists residential segregation based on race in the US
In the United States, voter files contain voters’ addresses

The FLCensus.csv data set contains the names of Florida counties and their corresponding county codes

The county codes are used to identify the counties in the voter file
The county names are used to identify the counties in the census data set

How does knowledge of residence location improve the prediction of individual race?

\(P(\textrm{race | surname and residence})\)

title: Probability and Distribution
section: Predicting race using surname and residence location
text:
Predicting race using surname and residence location

By applying Bayes’ rule


\[
P(\textrm{race}| \textrm{surname and residence})=\frac{P(\textrm{surname| race and residence})P(\textrm{race|residence})}{P(\textrm{surname|residence})}
\]

\(P(r\textrm{race | residence})\) is available from the Florida census data

however, the other two conditional probabilities, \(P(\textrm{surname | race and residence})\) and \(P(\textrm{surname |residence})\), are not directly available either in the census name data set or the Florida census data set

make an additional assumption that a voter’s surname and residence location are independent of each other given race



\[
P(\textrm{surname}| \textrm{race and residence})=\frac{P(\textrm{surname and residence|race})}{P(\textrm{residence|race})}=\frac{P(\textrm{surname})}{P(\textrm{race})}
\]


This conditional independence assumption implies that once we know a voter’s race, their residence location does not give us any additional information about their surname
county - County census id of voting district
VTD - Voting district census id (only unique within county)
total.pop - Total population of voting district
white - Proportion of non-Hispanic Whites in voting district
black - Proportion of non-Hispanic African Americans in voting district
api - Proportion of non-Hispanic Asian and Pacific Islanders in voting district
hispanic - Proportion of voters of Hispanic origin in voting district
others - Proportion of the other racial groups in voting district
Bayes’ rule conditional on both B and C events

\(P(A|B,C)=\frac{P(B|A \textrm{ and } C)P(A|C)}{P(B|C)}\)

title: Probability and Distribution
text:
Random Variables and Probability Distributions

A random variable assigns a number to each event

two outcomes of a coin flip can be represented by a binary random variable where 1 indicates landing on heads and 0 denotes landing on tails

The values of random variables must represent mutually exclusive and exhaustive events
A random variable can be discrete or continuous

A discrete random variable can take on a finite or countably infinite number of values

e.g. the number of heads in 10 coin flips

A continuous random variable can take on any value within a given range

e.g. the height of a person





consider a random variable that represents one’s racial group using five unique integers

black = 1, white = 2, hispanic = 3, asian = 4, and others = 5
someone who self-identifies as African American and White will be assigned the value of 5 instead of taking the values of 1 and 2 at the same time

Once we define a random variable, we can formalize a probability model using the distribution of the random variable

title: Probability and Distribution
text:
Bernoullis Distributions

A Bernoulli distribution is a discrete probability distribution for a random variable, \(X\), that can take on only two possible outcomes

e.g. flipping a coin, where heads is represented by \(1\) and tails by \(0\)
The Bernoulli distribution is parameterized by the probability of success, \(p\), which is the probability of obtaining a \(1\)

The distribution of a discrete random variable can be characterized by the probability mass function (pmf)
The pmf \(f(x)\) of a random variable \(X\) is defined as the probability that the random variable takes a particular value, i.e. \(f(x) = P(X = x)\)
The pmf of a Bernoulli distribution is given by


\[
f(x) = \begin{cases}
p & \textrm{if } x = 1 \\
1-p & \textrm{if } x = 0 \\
0 & \textrm{otherwise }
\end{cases}
\]

title: Probability and Distribution
text:
Uniform Distribution

A uniform distribution is a continuous probability distribution where all outcomes are equally likely within a specified range, \([a,b]\)

The uniform distribution is parameterized by two parameters, \(a\) and \(b\), which represent the lower and upper bounds of the distribution, respectively

use the (probability) density function (pdf) \(f(x)\) to quantifies the likelihood that a continuous random variable \(X\) will take a specific value \(x\)
The pdf of a uniform distribution is given by


\[
f(x) = \begin{cases}
\frac{1}{b-a} & \textrm{if } a \leq x \leq b \\
0 & \textrm{otherwise}
\end{cases}
\]

the CDF of a uniform distribution is given by



\[
F(x) = \begin{cases}
0 & \textrm{if } x < a \\
\frac{x-a}{b-a} & \textrm{if } a \leq x < b \\
1 & \textrm{if } x \geq b
\end{cases}
\]

in general, the CDF of a continuous random variable \(X\) can be expressed as



\[
F(x) = P(X ≤ x) = \int_{-\infty}^{x} f(t) dt
\]




Code
dunif(0.5, min=0, max=1)


punif(1, min=-2, max=2)

title: Probability and Distribution

Bernoulli and Uniform Distributions

We can use a uniform random variable to generate a Bernoulli random variable
in order to generate a Bernoulli random variable \(Y\) with success probability \(p\), we can first sample a uniform random variable \(X\) and then set \(Y = 1\) when \(X\) is less than \(p\) (similarly, set \(Y = 0\) if \(X ≥ p\)) so that Y takes a value of 1 with probability \(p\)

set.seed(123)

p <- 0.5 # success probabilities

x <- runif(sims, min = 0, max = 1) # uniform [0,1]

head(x)

head(y)

mean(y)

title: Probability and Distribution
text:
binomial distribution

a binomial random variable \(X\) records the number of successes in a total of \(n\) independent and identical trials with success probability \(p\)

e.g. the number of heads in \(10\) coin flips

The probability mass function of a binomial random variable with success probability \(p\) and \(n\) trials is given by


\[
f(x) = P(X = x) = \binom{n}{x} p^x (1-p)^{n-x}
\]

where \(\binom{n}{x}\) is the binomial coefficient, which represents the number of ways to choose \(x\) successes from \(n\) trials

title: Probability and Distribution
text:
Normal Distribution

A normal distribution is a continuous probability distribution that is symmetric about its mean, \(\mu\), and characterized by its standard deviation, \(\sigma\)

The normal distribution is often referred to as the Gaussian distribution

The probability density function (pdf) of a normal distribution is given by


\[
f(x) = \frac{1}{\sigma \sqrt{2\pi}} e^{-\frac{(x - \mu)^2}{2\sigma^2}} \quad \textrm{for } -\infty < x < \infty
\]

The cumulative distribution function (cdf) of a normal distribution is given by



\[
F(x) = P(X ≤ x) = \int_{-\infty}^{x} f(t) dt \quad \textrm{for } -\infty < x < \infty
\]

\(X \sim N(\mu, \sigma^2)\); when \(\mu=0\) and \(\sigma^2=1\), \(X\) is said to follow standard normal distribution



notice that the cdf of a normal distribution does not have a closed-form expression, but it can be computed using numerical methods

title: Probability and Distribution
text:
Normal Distribution

The normal distribution \(X \sim N(\mu, \sigma^2)\) has two important properties. Let \(c\) be a constant

let \(Z=X+c\), then \(Z \sim N(\mu+c, \sigma^2)\)
let \(Z=cX\), then \(Z \sim N(c\mu, c^2\sigma^2)\)

z-score of a normal random variable \(X\) is defined as


\[
\textrm{z-score} = \frac{X - \mu}{\sigma} \sim N(0,1)
\]

title: Probability and Distribution
text:
Normal Distribution

note that when the data are distributed according to the normal distribution

about two-thirds are within \(1\) standard deviation from the mean
approximately 95% are within the \(2\) standard deviations from the mean



\[
P(\mu - k\sigma \leq X \leq \mu + k\sigma) \approx \begin{cases}
0.68 & \textrm{if } k = 1 \\
0.95 & \textrm{if } k = 2 \\
0.997 & \textrm{if } k = 3
\end{cases}
\]

we can express the above probabilities in terms of z-score



\[
P(\mu - k\sigma \leq X \leq \mu + k\sigma) = P(-k \leq Z \leq k)=F(k) - F(-k)
\]

use the pnorm() function in R to compute the cumulative distribution function of a normal distribution





Code
pnorm(1) - pnorm(-1) # probability of being within 1 standard deviation from the mean

pnorm(2) - pnorm(-2) # probability of being within 2 standard deviations from the mean

pnorm(3) - pnorm(-3) # probability of being within 3 standard deviations from the mean



we can directly specify mean and standard deviation





Code
mu <- 5
sigma <- 2

pnorm(mu + sigma, mean = mu, sd = sigma) - pnorm(mu - sigma, mean = mu, sd = sigma)

pnorm(mu + 2 * sigma, mean = mu, sd = sigma) - pnorm(mu - 2 * sigma, mean = mu, sd = sigma)

title: Probability and Distribution
text:
Expectation

we used means and standard deviations in order to measure the center and spread of a distribution
Sample mean refers to the average of a variable in a particular data set
the expectation (or population mean) represents the mean value under a probability distribution
Sample mean fluctuates from one sample to another

but the expectation of a random variable is of a theoretical nature and is fixed given a probability model

The expectation of a random variable \(X\) is defined as


\[
E(X) = \sum_{x} x \cdot P(X = x)
\]

where the sum is taken over all possible values of \(X\) and \(P(X = x)\) is the probability mass function of the random variable \(X\)


The expectation of a continuous random variable \(X\) is defined as



\[
E(X) = \int_{-\infty}^{\infty} x \cdot f(x) dx
\]

where \(f(x)\) is the probability density function of the random variable \(X\)

title: Probability and Distribution
text:
Expectation - some examples

Consider a Bernoulli random variable \(X\) with success probability \(p\)

The expectation of a Bernoulli random variable is given by



\[
E(X) = 0 \cdot (1-p) + 1 \cdot p = p
\]

Consider a binomial random variable \(X\) with success probability \(p\) and \(n\) trials

The expectation of a binomial random variable is given by




\[
E(X) = \sum_{x=0}^{n} x \cdot P(X = x) = \sum_{x=0}^{n} x \cdot \binom{n}{x} p^x (1-p)^{n-x} = n \cdot p
\]

Consider a uniform random variable \(X\) with the interval \([a, b]\)

The expectation of a uniform random variable is given by




\[
E(X) = \int_{a}^{b} x \cdot f(x) dx = \int_{a}^{b} x \cdot \frac{1}{b-a} dx = \frac{a + b}{2}
\]

title: Probability and Distribution
text:
Expectation - some properties

Let \(X\) and \(Y\) be random variables and \(a\) and \(b\) be arbitrary constants
The expectation is a linear operator that satisfies the following equality


\[
E(aX + bY) = aE(X) + bE(Y)
\]

Example - the expectation of a binomial random variable \(X\) with success probability \(p\) and \(n\) trials



\[
E(X) = E\left(\sum_{i=1}^{n} Y_i\right) = \sum_{i=1}^{n} E(Y_i) = nE(Y_1) = np
\]

where \(Y_i\) is a Bernoulli random variable with success probability \(p\) and \(E(Y_i) = p\)


A key result: if \(X\) and \(Y\) are independent random variables, then



\[
E(XY) = E(X)E(Y)
\]

title: Probability and Distribution
text:
Variance

The variance of a random variable \(X\) is a measure of the spread of the distribution of \(X\) around its expectation
The variance of a random variable \(X\) is defined as


\[
\textrm{Var}(X) = E((X - E(X))^2) = E(X^2) - (E(X))^2
\]

the expectation of \(X^2\) is called the second moment of the random variable \(X\)
the square root of the variance is called the standard deviation of the random variable \(X\)
example

the variance of a Bernoulli random variable \(X\) with success probability \(p\) is given by




\[
\textrm{Var}(X) = E(X^2) - (E(X))^2 = p(1-p) - p^2 = p(1-p)
\]

title: Probability and Distribution
text:
Variance - properties

Let \(X\) and \(Y\) be random variables and \(a\) and \(b\) be arbitrary constants
The variance operator \(V\) has the following properties

\(V(a)=0\)
\(V(X+b) = V(X)\)
\(V(aX) = a^2V(X)\)

if \(X\) and \(Y\) are independent, \(V(aX + bY) = a^2V(X) + b^2V(Y)\)
Example 1

the variance of a binomial random variable \(X\) with success probability \(p\) and \(n\) trials is given by



\[
V(X) = V\left(\sum_{i=1}^{n} Y_i\right) = \sum_{i=1}^{n} V(Y_i) = nV(Y_1) = np(1-p)
\]

where \(Y_i\) is a Bernoulli random variable with success probability \(p\) and \(V(Y_i) = p(1-p)\)


Example 2

the variance of the sum of two independent normal random variable \(X \sim N(\mu_X, \sigma^2_X)\) and \(Y \sim N(\mu_Y, \sigma^2_Y)\) can be computed as




\[
V(X + Y) = V(X) + V(Y) = \sigma^2_X + \sigma^2_Y
\]

title: Probability and Distribution
text:
Predicting election outcomes with uncertainty
MC simulation

assume that for each hypothetical sampling, we will interview \(1000\) voters who are randomly selected from the population
The binomial distribution with success probability \(p\) and size \(1000\) within each state will model Obama’s support estimate

Using Monte Carlo simulation, we estimate Obama’s support within each state, then allocate that state’s Electoral College votes to the winning candidate
repeat this procedure many times to describe the uncertainty in pre-election polling estimates that is due to sampling variability
use the rbinom() function in \(R\) and the prob argument of this function can take a vector of success probabilities




Code
set.seed(123)

sim_election <- function(.id, df, n_draws = 1000) {
    ## for each state randomly sample
    mutate(df, draws = rbinom(n(), n_draws, p)) %>%
    filter(draws > (n_draws / 2)) %>%
    summarize(EV = sum(EV), .id = .id)
}

title: Probability and Distribution
section: Predicting election outcomes with uncertainty - MC simulation
text:
Predicting election outcomes with uncertainty - MC simulation

assume that for each hypothetical sampling, we will interview \(1000\) voters who are randomly selected from the population
The binomial distribution with success probability \(p\) and size \(1000\) within each state will model Obama’s support estimate

Using Monte Carlo simulation, we estimate Obama’s support within each state, then allocate that state’s Electoral College votes to the winning candidate
repeat this procedure many times to describe the uncertainty in pre-election polling estimates that is due to sampling variability
use the rbinom() function in \(R\) and the prob argument of this function can take a vector of success probabilities

then plot the results as a histogram - with a reference line for Obama’s actual number of electoral votes \((364)\)

library(purrr)

sims<- 10000

sim_results <- map_df(seq_len(sims),

ggplot(sim_results, aes(x=EV, y=..density..)) +
  geom_histogram(bins=12, fill="lightblue", color="black") +
  geom_vline(xintercept=364, linetype="dashed", linewidth=0.5, color="red") +
  labs(title="Distribution of Electoral Votes for Obama",
       x="Obama’s Electoral College votes",
       y="Density") +
  theme_minimal()



the mean and median values are lower than the actual number of Obama’s votes





Code

  select(EV) %>% 
  summarize_all(list(mean=mean, 
                     median=median,
