While the highest density of the histogram roughly corresponds to the actual number of Electoral College votes Obama won, the distribution of predictions is skewed

title: Probability and Distribution
section: Predicting election outcomes with uncertainty - MC simulation
text:
Predicting election outcomes with uncertainty - MC simulation

We can also compute the expected value of Obama’s Electoral College votes using the probability model

The expected value is the average of all possible outcomes, weighted by their probabilities

We can also analytically compute the expected value of Obama’s Electoral College votes under this probability model
Let \(S_j\) represent the number of respondents (among a total of \(1000\) respondents) for a pre-election poll who express support for Obama in state \(j\)
We use \(v_j\) to denote the number of Electoral College votes for state \(j\)

the expected number of Obama’s Electoral College votes is



\[
E(\textrm{Obama's votes}) = \sum_{j=1}^{51} E(\textrm{Obama wins state j}) \cdot v_j = \sum_{j=1}^{51} P(S_j > 500) \cdot v_j
\]

where \(P(S_j > 500)\) is the probability that Obama wins state \(j\) in the pre-election poll


the variance of Obama’s Electoral College votes can be computed as



\[
V(\textrm{Obama's predicted votes}) = \sum_{j=1}^{51} V(v_j \mathbb{I}\{S_j > 500\}) = \sum_{j=1}^{51} P(S_j > 500)(1 - P(S_j > 500)) \cdot v_j^2
\]

where \(\mathbb{I}\{S_j > 500\}\) is an indicator function that equals \(1\) if Obama wins state \(j\) and \(0\) otherwise


use use the pbinom() function, which evaluates the cdf of the binomial distribution at its input value





Code
n_draws <- 1000

pres08 %>%
  mutate(pb = pbinom(n_draws / 2, size = n_draws, prob = p, lower.tail = FALSE)) %>%
  summarize(mean = sum(pb * EV),
            median = sum(EV * (pb > 0.5)),
            var = sum(pb * (1-pb)*EV^2),
            sd = sqrt(var))

title: Probability and Distribution
text:
Permutations - The birthday problem
\[
\begin{align*}
\implies \log P(\textrm{nobody has the same birthday}) & \\
= \log 365! - k \log 365 - \log(365-k)!
\end{align*}
\]

use R to compute the probability




Code
# create a new function
birthday <- function(k) {
                  logdenom <- k * log(365) + lfactorial(365 - k)
                  lognumer <- lfactorial(365)
                  pr <- 1 - exp(lognumer - logdenom)
                  pr
}






Code
library(tidyverse)

# create a data frame with k values from 1 to 100

k_values <- tibble(k = 1:100) %>%
  mutate(probability = birthday(k))

# plot the probability

ggplot(k_values, 
       aes(x = k, y = probability)) +
  geom_line() +
  geom_point() +
  geom_hline(yintercept = 0.5, linetype = "dashed", color = "red") +
  labs(title = "Probability of at least two people having the same birthday",
       x = "Number of people (k)",
       y = "Probability") +
  theme_minimal() +
  scale_y_continuous(
    str_c("Probability that at least two", "people have the same birthday", sep = "\n"),
    limits = c(0, 1), 
    breaks = seq(0, 1, by = 0.1))






when the number of people equals \(23\), the probability of at least two people having the same birthday exceeds \(0.5\)

when the number of people is more than \(50\), this probability is close to \(1\)




Birthday problem: the answer is only 23 people, which is much lower than what most people think
To solve this problem using permutations, first notice the following relationship:

\(P(\textrm{at least two people have the same birthday}= 1 − P(\textrm{nobody has the same birthday})\)

Let \(k\) be the number of people

the number of ways in which \(k\) unique birthdays can be arranged out of 365 days

\(_{365}P_k = \frac{365!}{(365-k)!}\)

the total number of elements in the sample space is equal to the total number of ways to select \(k\) possibly non-unique birthdays out of 365 days

\(P(\textrm{nobody has the same birthday})\)= \(\frac{\textrm{# of ways in which k unique birthdays can be arranged}}{\textrm{# of ways in which k possibly nonunique birthdays can be arranged}}\)

the number of ways in which \(k\) unique birthdays can be arranged is given by \(_{365}P_k = \frac{365!}{(365-k)!}\)
the total number of ways in which \(k\) possibly nonunique birthdays can be arranged is given by \(365^k\)

this is because each person can have any of the 365 days as their birthday, and there are \(k\) people

thus, the probability that nobody has the same birthday is given by

\(P(\textrm{nobody has the same birthday}) = \frac{_{365}P_k}{365^k} = \frac{365!}{(365-k)! \cdot 365^k}\)

title: Probability and Distribution
text:
Independence

if we have three events A, B, and C, the joint independence among these events implies that the joint probability can be written as the product of marginal probabilities


\[
P(A \textrm{ and } B \textrm{ and } C) = P(A) \cdot P(B) \cdot P(C)
\]

The conditional independence of events A and B given event C implies that the joint probability of A and B given C is equal to the product of two conditional probabilities



\[
P(A \textrm{ and } B | C) = P(A | C) \cdot P(B | C)
\]

notice that joint independence implies pairwise independence



This result can be obtained by applying the law of total probability: \[
\begin{align*}
P(\textrm{A and B}) &= P(\textrm{A and B and C}) + P({\textrm{A and B and } C^c}) \\
&= P(A)P(B)P(C) + P(A)P(B)P(C^c) \\
&= P(A)P(B)\{P(C) + P(C^c)\} = P(A)P(B)
\end{align*}
\]

title: Probability and Distribution
text:
Bayes’ rule

A well-known application of Bayes’ rule is the interpretation of medical diagnostic tests
Consider the following first-trimester screening test problem

A 35-year-old pregnant woman is told that 1 in 378 women of her age will have a baby with Down syndrome (DS)
A first-trimester ultrasound screening procedure indicates that she is in a high-risk category (HR)
Of 100 cases of DS, 86 mothers will receive a high-risk result (HR) and 14 cases of DS will be missed
Also, there is a 1 in 20 chance for a non-high-risk pregnancy to be diagnosed as high risk

Given the result of the screening procedure

what is the probability that her baby has DS?
What would the probability be if the result had been negative?




P(DS | HR) = \(\frac{P(HR | DS) P(DS)}{P(HR)}= \frac{P(HR | DS) P(DS)}{P(HR | DS)P(DS) + P(HR | \textrm{not DS})P(\textrm{not DS})}=\frac{0.86*\frac{1}{378}}{0.86*\frac{1}{378}+ 0.05*\frac{377}{378}}\approx 0.04\)
P(DS | ) = \(\frac{P(\textrm{not HR} | DS) P(DS)}{P(\textrm{not HR})}= \frac{P(\textrm{not HR} | DS) P(DS)}{P(\textrm{not HR} | DS)P(DS) + P(\textrm{not HR} | \textrm{not DS})P(\textrm{not DS})}=\frac{0.14*\frac{1}{378}}{0.14*\frac{1}{378}+ 0.95*\frac{377}{378}}\approx 0.0005\)

title: Probability and Distribution
section: Predicting race using surname and residence location
text:
Predicting race using surname and residence location
\[
P(\textrm{surname|residence})=\sum_{\textrm{race}} P(\textrm{surname|race})P(\textrm{race|residence})
\]

\(P(\textrm{surname|race})\) is not directly available from the dataset, but can be obtained by using Bayes’ rule


\[
P(\textrm{surname|race})=\frac{P(\textrm{race|surname})P(\textrm{surname})}{P(\textrm{race})}
\]

\(P(\textrm{race})\) can be computed from the Florida census data by using the law of total probability

\(P(\textrm{race})=\sum\limits_{\textrm{residence}}P(\textrm{race|residence}) P(\textrm{residence})\)






Code
library(tidyverse)

# load the data
FLCensus <- read_csv("https://raw.githubusercontent.com/kwan-MSDA/soci7016_2025/refs/heads/main/data/FLCensusVTD.csv")

FLCensus<- FLCensus %>% 
  rename("asian"="api", "other"="others")

race_prop <- FLCensus %>%
  select(total.pop, white, black, asian, hispanic, other) %>%
  pivot_longer(cols = - total.pop, names_to = "race",
               values_to = "pct") %>%
  group_by(race) %>%
  summarize(race_prop = weighted.mean(pct, w = total.pop)) %>%
  arrange(desc(race_prop))

race_prop



compute \(P(\textrm{surname | race})\)

use the left_join() function to add the race_prop data to the FLVotersJoin data
then record the total number of names in the cnames data for later use






Code
## merge the race probability with the existing data
FLVotersJoin<- left_join(FLVotersJoin, race_prop, by="race")

## calculate prob of surname given race total number of individuals
total.count<- sum(cnames$count)

cnames_reshape<- cnames %>% 
  select(-race_pred, -highest_pct) %>%
  pivot_longer(cols=starts_with("pct"),
               names_to="race",
               values_to="pct") %>% 
  mutate(race=str_replace(race, "pct", ""),
         race=recode(race, "api"="asian", "others"="other"),
         race_surname=pct/100) %>% 
  select(-pct) %>% 
  left_join(race_prop, by="race") %>% 
  mutate(prob_surname_race=race_surname * (count/total.count)/race_prop) %>% 
  rename("posib_race"=race)

cnames_reshape

title: Probability and Distribution
section: Predicting race using surname and residence location
text:
Predicting race using surname and residence location

compute \(P(\textrm{surname | residence})\)
merge the Florida census data into the voter file data after reshaping to make sure it matches
merge in the reshaped cnames data
calculate the necessary quantity per race, then separately sum those quantities and merge the result back in




Code
## reshape the FL census data so we have race as a variable, then pct of pop
merge_temp <- FLCensus %>%
  pivot_longer(cols = c(white, black, hispanic, asian, other),
               names_to = "pop_race",
               values_to = "pop_pct") %>%
  inner_join(voters, by = c("county", "VTD")) %>%
  inner_join(cnames_reshape, by = c("surname",
                                    "pop_race" = "posib_race")) %>%
  mutate(race_residence = prob_surname_race * pop_pct)

## then calculate the summation
name_residence <- merge_temp %>%
  group_by(surname, county, VTD) %>%
  summarize(name_residence = sum(race_residence))



now we have all quantities of interest, can merge all together and calculate the predicted race





Code
FLVoters_full <- merge_temp %>%
  inner_join(name_residence, by = c("surname", "county", "VTD")) %>%
  mutate(pred_race = prob_surname_race * pop_pct / name_residence) %>%
  select(surname, pop_race, race, pred_race, county, VTD)




What is crucial here is making sure we are merging with the correct fields specified to match between the data.



see whether the highest predicted race estimate matches the actual race given by the respondent





Code
## filter to save the highest predicted race and see if it matches actual race

FL_updated <- FLVoters_full %>%
  ungroup() %>%
  group_by(surname, county, VTD) %>%
  ## select row per name with the largest percentage
  ## by keeping the first instance after arranging by percentage
  filter(row_number(desc(pred_race)) == 1) %>%
  ## ungroup to avoid errors later
  ungroup()

## calculate the new true positive rate
race_tp_new <- FL_updated %>%
  group_by(race) %>%
  summarize(tp = mean(race == pop_race)) %>%
  arrange(desc(tp))

race_tp_new



proportion of African Americans among those with surname “White”





Code
filter(cnames, surname == "WHITE") %>%
  select(pctblack) %>%
  pull()



predicted probability of being African American given residence location





Code
filter(FLVoters_full, surname == "WHITE", pop_race == "black") %>%
  select(pred_race) %>%
  summary()



compute the false positive rate for each race





Code
race_fp_new <- FL_updated %>%
  group_by(pop_race) %>%
  summarize(fp = mean(race != pop_race)) %>%
  arrange(desc(fp))

race_fp_new




the true positive rate is much improved for Black American, jumping from 16% to 63%
Minor improvements are also made for Hispanic and Asian voters

suggesting that the location of a voter’s residence can be informative

For example, according to the census data, among people whose surname is “White,” 27% are African American
However, once we incorporate the location of their residence, the predicted probability of such individuals being African American ranges from 0% to 98%

This implies that we predict some voters to be highly likely African American and other voters to be highly likely non–African American

the false positive rate for Whites is reduced, from 20% to 12%

This is in large part due to the fact that many of the African American voters who were incorrectly classified as Whites using surname alone are now predicted to be African American
We also see decreases in the false positive rate for African Americans, though it remains similar for the other races

title: Probability and Distribution
text:
Bernoullis Distributions

the cumulative distribution function (CDF), \(F(x)\) represents the cumulative probability that a random variable \(X\) takes a value equal to or less than a specific value x, i.e., \(F(x) = P(X ≤ x)\)
the relationship between the PMF \(f(x)\) and the CDF \(F(x)\) for a discrete random variable can be written as


\[
F(x) = P(X ≤ x)=  \sum_{k\leq x} f(k)
\]

where \(k\) represents all values the random variable \(X\) can take that are less than or equal to \(x\)
The CDF of a Bernoulli distribution is given by



\[
F(x) = \begin{cases}
0 & \textrm{if } x < 0 \\
1-p & \textrm{if } 0 \leq x < 1 \\
1 & \textrm{if } x \geq 1
\end{cases}
\]

title: Probability and Distribution
text:
Bernoulli Distributions

A Bernoulli distribution is a discrete probability distribution for a random variable, \(X\), that can take on only two possible outcomes

e.g. flipping a coin, where heads is represented by \(1\) and tails by \(0\)
The Bernoulli distribution is parameterized by the probability of success, \(p\), which is the probability of obtaining a \(1\)

The distribution of a discrete random variable can be characterized by the probability mass function (pmf)
The pmf \(f(x)\) of a random variable \(X\) is defined as the probability that the random variable takes a particular value, i.e. \(f(x) = P(X = x)\)
The pmf of a Bernoulli distribution is given by


\[
f(x) = \begin{cases}
p & \textrm{if } x = 1 \\
1-p & \textrm{if } x = 0 \\
0 & \textrm{otherwise }
\end{cases}
\]

text:
Bernoulli Distributions

the cumulative distribution function (CDF), \(F(x)\) represents the cumulative probability that a random variable \(X\) takes a value equal to or less than a specific value x, i.e., \(F(x) = P(X ≤ x)\)
the relationship between the PMF \(f(x)\) and the CDF \(F(x)\) for a discrete random variable can be written as


\[
F(x) = P(X ≤ x) =  \sum_{k\leq x} f(k)
\]

where \(k\) represents all values the random variable \(X\) can take that are less than or equal to \(x\)


The CDF of a Bernoulli distribution is given by



\[
F(x) = \begin{cases}
0 & \textrm{if } x < 0 \\
1-p & \textrm{if } 0 \leq x < 1 \\
1 & \textrm{if } x \geq 1
\end{cases}
\]

title: Probability and Distribution
text:
binomial distribution

the cdf of a binomial random variable is given by


\[
F(x) = P(X ≤ x) = \sum_{k=0}^{x} \binom{n}{k} p^k (1-p)^{n-k}
\]

for \(x = 0, 1, ..., n\)


use R to compute the probability of getting exactly \(2\) heads in \(10\) flips of a fair coin





Code
dbinom(2, size = 10, prob = 0.5) # probability of getting 2 heads in 10 flips



the cdf of a binomial random variable can be computed using the pbinom() function





Code
pbinom(2, size = 10, prob = 0.5) # probability of getting at most 2 heads in 10 flips




a binomial random variable is the sum of n independently and identically distributed (or i.i.d. in short) Bernoulli random variables
Recall that a Bernoulli random variable equals either 1 or 0 with success probability p

Thus, X can take an integer value from 0 to n

title: Probability and Distribution
section: Example - Predicting election outcomes with uncertainty
text:
Example - Predicting election outcomes with uncertainty

the prediction of election outcomes using pre-election polls

the prediction of election outcomes is often based on pre-election polls, which are surveys conducted to estimate the preferences of voters before an election

polling has sampling variability because we only interview a fraction of a large population
Let us focus our discussion on the US 2008 election

Suppose that the Election Day outcome represents the true proportion of Obama and McCain supporters in the population of voters within each state and we assume that the fraction of voters who support a third-party candidate is negligible

the two-party support rate for Obama \(p_j\), and McCain \(1 − p_j\), within each state \(j\)


The CSV data file pres08.csv contains the 2008 US presidential election result




Code
library(tidyverse)

pres08<- read_csv("https://raw.githubusercontent.com/kwan-MSDA/soci7016_2025/refs/heads/main/data/pres08.csv")


glimpse(pres08)

pres08<- pres08 %>% 
  mutate(p=Obama/(Obama+ McCain))




Suppose that we conduct a preelection poll under exactly the same conditions multiple times

Each time, we obtain a representative sample of the target population and yet the sample consists of different voters
This means that the estimated support for a candidate will differ for each sample

library(purrr)

ggplot(sim_results, aes(x=EV, y=..density..)) +

the mean and median values are lower than the actual number of Obama’s votes



Code
sim_results %>% 
  select(EV) %>%

                     median=median,

title: Probability and Distribution
text:
Predicting election outcomes with uncertainty

We can also compute the expected value of Obama’s Electoral College votes using the probability model

The expected value is the average of all possible outcomes, weighted by their probabilities

Let \(S_j\) represent the number of respondents (among a total of \(1000\) respondents) for a pre-election poll who express support for Obama in state \(j\)
We use \(v_j\) to denote the number of Electoral College votes for state \(j\)

the expected number of Obama’s Electoral College votes is



\[
E(\textrm{Obama's votes}) = \sum_{j=1}^{51} E(\textrm{Obama wins state j}) \cdot v_j = \sum_{j=1}^{51} P(S_j > 500) \cdot v_j
\]

where \(P(S_j > 500)\) is the probability that Obama wins state \(j\) in the pre-election poll

title: Probability and Distribution
text:
Predicting election outcomes with uncertainty

the variance of Obama’s Electoral College votes can be computed as


\[
\begin{align*}
V(\textrm{Obama's predicted votes}) &= \sum_{j=1}^{51} V(v_j \mathbb{I}\{S_j > 500\}) \\
& = \sum_{j=1}^{51} P(S_j > 500)(1 - P(S_j > 500)) \cdot v_j^2
\end{align*}
\]

where \(\mathbb{I}\{S_j > 500\}\) is an indicator function that equals \(1\) if Obama wins state \(j\) and \(0\) otherwise


use use the pbinom() function, which evaluates the cdf of the binomial distribution at its input value





Code
n_draws <- 1000

pres08 %>%
  mutate(pb = pbinom(n_draws / 2, size = n_draws, prob = p, lower.tail = FALSE)) %>%
  summarize(mean = sum(pb * EV),
            median = sum(EV * (pb > 0.5)),
            var = sum(pb * (1-pb)*EV^2),
            sd = sqrt(var))
